text: it kind of makes me wonder if we'll ever
get to a point where people aren't
chasing the next programming language
because like all of us are happy using
go for all sorts of things but I've I've
already now and go is not even that old
but I've had people tell me who are
prominent in the go community that they
feel like go is dying and that some
other language is the new thing and I
think they told me that you know just
for various reasons but like I've heard
it and it's like weird to hear because
I'm like go is not that old and like the
amount of things like PHP and P are
still powering is out and people still
build stuff in those languages so I'm
like why would go just randomly die you
know all a sudden but but I think part
of that is that like hype thing where
depending on the industry you're in like
as an example if you create courses like
I do or if you do like corporate
training or if you do you know like
anything along those like along those
lines where you're helping companies
come up to speed with something new I
feel like you're almost enticed and
encouraged to follow that hype train and
like help produce more hype about
something new even if you know it's not
better for the people that you're
actually trying to help yeah I think
this really does come back to like us as
an industry being so extremely hype
focused I mean it's it's it's literally
everywhere like we're going through the
AI hype cycle right now where everybody
like a is gonna Gonna Change how
everything we do works and it's like
yeah there'll be change but it's like
it's not it's not going to revolutionize
things in that way I think like
microservices was the same way and
event- driven architecture was the same
way and I mean way probably agile was
the same way back 20 years ago where
it's just kind of like oh this will be
the one thing that fixes our problems
but I think like at the end of the day
our problem is that we're very bad at
teaching people deep things as an
industry like my own Journey trying to
just like learn about distributed
systems so I can teach other people
about distributed systems has been like
extremely challenging because like so
much of the literature is a very old so
that's an immediate P that we have right
now because I think a lot of people are
like oh this book was published in 2015
it's it's too old it's too irrelevant we
shouldn't be reading it um and some of
the stuff I'm reading is from like
1980 um but I think it's also that like
it's sometimes tough to actually like
really dig down and understand like the
reasoning behind why you want to learn
something or what relevance it really
has um and I think the the kind of
underlying problem is not that like most
people are doing this I think it's fine
if most people are chasing the hype
cycle but I where I think the problem
comes in is when the people that want to
create the next foundational technology
only understand surface level things and
I think that happens a lot where it's
like oh yeah like I want to use uh like
example I'm dealing with around this
right now is like with rest where I'm
like actually trying to like learn rest
and I'm reading Roy fielding's
dissertation and it's like a infuriating
because the things he mentions I'm like
hey this is like you could have written
this yesterday and it'd be equally a
applicable to like our entire state of
the world so that feels kind of bad
since it was written like a quarter
century ago at this point but also like
just how brilliant of a design the you
know the system underlines the web
actually is and then you contrast that
with how quickly people want to throw
out that design now because they have
particular gripes with it not
understanding that know that gripe is
actually like a a kind of a feature it's
not a bug it's a feature of the system
and enables all of this other stuff and
I think that those small features that
small bit of nuance like often gets kind
of papered over when people want to you
know just be part of the hype cycle or
just kind of gets thrown out and so
people are like oh this this thing we
need to get rid of this thing we need to
get rid of this problem and the so the
next set of people that are building
things are just kind of like oh okay
well that's the problem we have to solve
even though that's could be an
unsolvable problem or not a problem that
we should be focusing on um and I think
like you know this you know I guess one
of the reasons I brought this up is
because when I look at kofka or this
kind of event driven architecture things
I see like what could have been with the
web or with rest in general like this
could have been built as a restful
system and how powerful that would have
been to have these systems within our
organizations but we just don't have
that and the reason we don't have that
is because people don't understand what
rest is or what these older Technologies
are and reading and learning them
requires you to go back and read a 160
page long disertation from 2000 which is
not what the majority of people in our
industry are going to do so I think
that's like the the the point of
contention that we have at the
moment
